issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: We have sort job where reduce attempt does not send heartbeat in timely manner to application master. The AM should kick off another attempt to let job succeeds. What we find is the job fails and there is no speculation happening.
fields.summary: Speculative execution does not function for reduce

comments.body:
When the reduce attempt is paused. It will not update its own estimatedRunTime (because it will process any events that it receives) which will not trigger the speculative.

The simple method could be :
1. Save the previous estimatedRunTime and progress as history data
2. Compare current estimatedRunTime and current progress with the history data, if they are the same, we will need to manually kick off the taskAttemptStatusUpdate.

Should we allow some lag time before marking the history data as no-progress? I am concerned if this method can cause many false positive speculation. Can you please make some inputs if this is unlikely to happen?

bq.Should we allow some lag time before marking the history data as no-progress? I am concerned if this method can cause many false positive speculation. Can you please make some inputs if this is unlikely to happen?

Originally, between the two continous scheduler TaskAttempUpdate events, estimatedRunTime will not change. The changes that I have made will keep estimatedRunTime update everytime that Speculator calls. 

I agree that we may need to add some lag time between each changes.

[~ojoshi] Any good reason why we do not want to do that ? I'd like to keep the original event flow.

Using certain finite calls, then manually do the update is not a good way.
Set a timer instead.

This message is automatically generated.

I presume this is not just for reduces. Even maps that are 'paused' will run into the same issue? If so, please edit the ticket title.

Also we already have code to handle this. Though estimatedRunTime doesn't change for paused task-attempts, we look at estimatedEndTime, estimatedReplacementEndTime and speculate if needed. That code should just work fine even in this case, although it is clear there is some bug somewhere. This isn't the correct fix, let's investigate more.
Surprisingly map speculation works correctly. Only reduce has this issue.

bq. Surprisingly map speculation works correctly. Only reduce has this issue.
Do you have only one reducer in this job or multiple? How many?
I have 8-12 reducers in this job.
Add testcases to test the logic

The changes looks fine to me given the current state of the speculation code. I think we need to clean up this code a lot, but I'll file a separate ticket.

Making trivial changes myself - formatting, java comments etc.

Same patch as Xuan's with the following modifications
 - Changed the waiting time to be 9 secs on 3 task-heartbeats
 - Added lots of java comments
 - Renamed variables/methods for better readability
 - Fixed formatting
 - Refactored test to not duplicate code
 - Increased test timeout so that it doesn't fail randomly due to timeouts

Will check this in when Jenkins says okay.

SUCCESS: Integrated in Hadoop-trunk-Commit #4538 (See [https://builds.apache.org/job/Hadoop-trunk-Commit/4538/])
MAPREDUCE-5533. Fixed MR speculation code to track any TaskAttempts that aren't heart-beating for a while, so that we can aggressively speculate instead of waiting for task-timeout. Contributed by Xuan Gong. (vinodkv: http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/?root=Apache-SVN&view=rev&rev=1529229)
